We have not had any major accidental releases, there have been minor releases, such as 
valve packing gland leaks, etc, and all of these leaks were identified and repaired 
immediately during our daily or weekly preventative checks.

As stated earlier, employee training is mandatory at our company. All of my refrigeration 
technicians have gone through a classroom training conducted by an external company, 
this same company has installed 100 % of our ammonia refrigeration. During this 
classroom training, we videotaped the entire training and we are presently using this as 
one of our training tools for future technicians.

Cloverdale Foods Company
RMP Executive Summary
By: Larry Huether, Plant Engineer
Date: 6-18-2004

Cloverdale Foods has been one of the leaders in our region for commitment to safety 
programs for many years with very strong support from our CEO/President, T.J. Russell.
Craig Engelhard, our Safety Manager, is a member of the AMI, American Meat Institute, 
safety committee. During these conferences, they have addressed topics of Process Safety 
Management for Ammonia Refrigeration, electrical safety, written SOP's dealing with 
threat and risk. And I plan on joining the IIAR this summer. We have a very good 
relationship with our local OSHA office, and have favorably united on different programs 
with them to create and maintain a safe facility as possible. To show another example for 
our commitment to our employees, we were the first food processing facility in the 
United States, to allow NIOSH to review our practices and procedures and used their 
recommendations to help our company be more efficient with proper procedures. We 
have monthly safety meetings that cover different safety topics. This will range from 
ammonia within our facility to safety awareness at home. Being a ready-to-eat food 
processor, food safety is an on going procedure on a daily basis.

Training is also considered to be very important at Cloverdale. Our Safety Manager has 
attended numerous safety seminars, and myself, Larry Huether, have completed the 
PSM/RMP schooling at Garden City Community College in Garden City, Kansas. I 
attended this school in May, I felt before attending that we had a very good RMP 
program, after the schooling, I learned on how I can even make it better.
We also had a RMP audit by E.P.A. auditors from the Denver, Colorado office on May 8, 
2002. After this audit, we updated our existing PHA, process safety information and the 
mechanical integrity program.

On an annual basis we meet with our local fire department. During this time we tour the 
entire facility, discuss anything that might be a danger to our facility or employees and 
revisit our emergency response program. 
Our emergency response program is: if we have a leak that is 50 ppm, we are trained to 
wear a MSA gas mask, if the leak reaches 300 ppm, all employees evacuate the building. 
At this time we contact our local fire department and inform them of an ammonia leak. 
Our fire department will then contact a local gas refinery company, Tesoro, which has 
trained personnel with the proper attire to respond to hazardous chemicals. During our 
orientation for new employees and monthly safety meetings, our employees have been 
explained where to congregate once leaving the building, depending on wind direction. 
And all supervisors have been trained on being accountable for the employees working in 
their department. The maintenance department has a hand held ammonia detector located 
outside the facility, which will be used to monitor the level of ammonia before reentering 
the building.

The system in place for ammonia detection is a Manning leak detection system. All of 
our ammonia compressors and vessels are in one room; therefore the detector is in the 
compressor room with the display outside in the maintenance shop area. If there is a leak, 
an alarm will sound in the shop, allowing any personnel to see the level of leak in the 
compressor room without entering the compressor room. If any individual is in the 
compressor room

and a leak is present, there is an orange light warning that the level is 
50 ppm, employees have been trained at this point, a MSA is required. If the level gets 
300 ppm, a complete evacuation of the facility is required.

All of our ammonia valve stations that control the evaporators inside the building are 
located outside on the roof. Therefore, if there are any leaks in any room, excluding the 
compressor room, it can be quickly isolated and controlled.

As stated earlier, we are a food manufacturing facility that produces sausage products, 
franks, hams and bacon. All of the anhydrous ammonia is used for refrigeration. The 
receiver, accumulators, and compressors are all located on the southeast corner of the 
building with an outside door in this room. We have approximately 15,600 #'s of 
ammonia in our systems. We have three separate systems in our facility. 1. a high suction 
that we use for processing rooms, 2. a medium suction that we use for product holding 
coolers, and 3. a low suction that is used for two blast freezers. There are room 
temperatures that need to be met to comply with our local U.S.D.A. regulations.

We have an intense preventative maintenance program established not only for the 
ammonia system, but also for all systems and equipment. This program ensures that all of 
the ammonia equipment and vessels along with its safety controls are operational and in 
running condition. Our PHA has been updated to comply with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.119 
and to meet the requirements of 40 CFR 68.67. During the audit, it was felt we were 
overly general on some items. Since then, we have broke it down even further to identify 
variations that present any unique hazards to our equipment, piping, human factors, etc¿

68.73. Before the audit our pipes and valves were not identified properly as
